Girl, woman, other! Reveiw. 
Rating: ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ
*I realy enjoyed this but it was a bit tricky to read: throughout the entire novel there was non full stops and the language/themes was definitly mature. It was a great insight into the lives of black woman, throughout different generations and of different sexual identities. I enjoyed the perspective slightly more with some characters and my fav sections were latisha and megan/morgan. It was so clever how all the lives intersect. 
Would recomend!

Hi hi hi lovelies! üòò 

I don‚Äôt really have a title for this list cause it‚Äôs more of a pandering, floopy conversation type post!

Do you guys ever buy a book but then never really want to read it? Because I know I wouldn‚Äôt have bought this if I didn‚Äôt like the sound of it but I have absolutely no desire to read it and it nearly bothers me a little seeing it in my shelf. Do you guys get like that sometimes?

But my reader heart doesn‚Äôt want to get rid of it in case it‚Äôs an amazing book and I miss out by not reading it but I don‚Äôt want to look at it on my shelf if I won‚Äôt read it and I don‚Äôt overly want to read it but I must‚Äôve bought it for a reason. Ya know? 

Lol I feel like this is really weird and other people don‚Äôt feel like this at all! 

Have any of you read this? Want did you think? Because I think it even won an award so it should be good.

Happy Reading ‚ù§Ô∏è

A cosy afternoon well spent. Reading is my absolute favourite thing to do in lockdown, and it‚Äôs such a great feeling when you find a book that you honestly can‚Äôt put down. Especially in the midst of a pandemic, turning to books can be a great escape. 

I still have no idea why it took me so long to get around to this one, even though its been sitting on my bookshelf for ages! 

What can I possibly say about this brilliant novel that hasn‚Äôt already been said? 

Well, I found it very moving and  decided to post a short review up on my website anyway.

Winsome
"Winsome is preparing a family favorite of roast breadfruit, fried flying  fish seasoned with onion and thyme, with a side of grilled yellow squash,  egglplant, zucchini and pan roasted mushrooms with a herb lemon sauce.  As the sea air breezes into the kitchen window through the mosquito mesh that stops the flies invading in the daytime. She appreciates healthy eating now. She is back home in Barbados and eating food grown in her vegetable garden and fish caught fresh. 

Her daughter Shirley is complaining about her terrible job in that terrible school in England and when Winsome advises her to leave the school, Shirley replies I don't sugesstions Mum, I just want you to listen. 

Winsome takes the fish out of the fridge, scales, fillets and slices it with her sharpest knife, runs it under the cold water, dips it in vinegar. She makes a marinade out of myrtle pepper, garlic, corriander, thyme and oil in a bowl, coats the fish, wraps in foil and puts it in the fridge."

An exerpt from "Girl, Woman, Other " by @bernardineevaristo

Enjoying a slow Sunday morning before returning to a (slightly) more normal routine of working from home tomorrow. 

What can I possibly say about this brilliant novel that hasn‚Äôt already been said? 

All I know is I‚Äôm loving it so far and it feels like the perfect book to kick off the New Year with. 

In Girl, Woman, Other the interconnected stories of a group of black British women raise timeless questions about feminism and race. The characters are so vivid and the writing is beautiful. It‚Äôs taken me way too long to finally read this book so I knew I absolutely had to bump it up to the very top of my 2021 TBR! No regrets there. 
.

Spring Break left me with a lot of reading time, so here‚Äôs some mini reviews of everything I read!

üö¢üë©üèº The Unsinkable Greta James by Jennifer E Smith- I really liked this one! It was a quick read with short chapters, and I really got lost in the Alaskan scenery. There could have been more character development for sure as some parts felt rushed but overall I thought it was a fun, quick read.

üë©üèæ‚Äç‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüíã‚Äçüë®üèºüè° Act Your Age, Eve Brown by Talia Hibbert- I absolutely loved this book! It‚Äôs the third in the Brown Sisters trilogy, and it did not disappoint. All the characters were great, and I felt were all developed really well. This was my favorite book of the three for sure.

‚õ≤Ô∏èü§´ The Fountains of Silence by Ruta Sepetys- This is an author that does not waste a word. AFOS was slower paced than some of her other books, but I honestly didn‚Äôt mind it. There were so many perspectives, and such a detailed and rich history of Spain during the dictatorship of Franco. Highly recommend for any historical fiction readers.

üëßüèæüåå Amari and the Night Brothers by B.B. Alston- This was so fun! I started it on a whim after reading some heavier books and it was the right move. The characters are great, the plot is great, the twists and turns are also great, and honestly I forgot this was a middle grade book. Looking forward to Book 2!

üëßüèæüë©üèæ Girl, Woman, Other by Bernardine Evaristo- I loved the style of this. It contained many interconnected stories based on a single character, who would have appeared in other chapters. I personally like this as it adds a new dimension to the stories being told. There is a bit of a non-traditional writing style, but it works to keep the reader‚Äôs attention. That being said, it is slow-paced and reflective, and I found myself putting it down and picking it up over the three weeks that I read it. 

üåÉüîç City of Glass by Cassandra Clare (reread)- I have way more questions than I do answers. All I need to say is Clary just needs to stop making out with people that could *potentially* be her brothers.

Have you read any of these?

-girl, woman, other by Bernardine Evaristo-

wow what can i say about this book that has not already been said. i found it really amazing, informative and compelling! i love the books that follow characters through their whole life, and this one follows 12 women with different sexualities, racial backgrounds and generations.  the writing style can be a bit hard to get into because of the sentence formation. sometimes it reads like poetry and/or non-fiction but i personally really liked it. all the narratives were very interesting and i found myself immersed in this book throughout. 

what did you think of it if you've read it?

Teeming with life and crackling with energy ‚Äî a love song to modern Britain and black womanhood, Girl, Woman, Other follows the lives and struggles of twelve very different characters. Mostly women, black and British, they tell the stories of their families, friends and lovers, across the country and through the years.

Joyfully polyphonic and vibrantly contemporary, this is a gloriously new kind of history, this winner of The Booker prize 2019 is a novel of our times: celebratory, ever-dynamic and utterly irresistible. 

.

Girl, Woman, Other 

I mainly got this to see what all the fuss was about, I've seen it all over bookstagram. So, naturally, when I saw it on the english shelf at work (I work in a bookstore) I got it.
And waow did I love it. At first I was a little bit unsure about the form. It's a lyrical roman. But I easily adjusted to it and found it quite charming. 

It felt amazing to read a book revolving women and a non-binary person. And especially POC women and a non-binary. And lesbians! 

Every chapter, or whatever I should call it, represent one person and we get to see how all their stories intertwine in the end pretty much.
I did find the intertwining part a little bit disappointing. The epilogue I found amazing when it connected dots, but the last chapter "After party" was very meh compared to all the amazing stories I had read before. I wish more would have happened. But I think the epilogue weighed it up. 

I do think it deserves all the love it has gotten. It was an amazing read.

The perfect novel for International Women‚Äôs Day üåà

There just is so much to be celebrated in Evaristo's irresistible GIRL, WOMAN, OTHER, a novel that not only captures the inner lives of women with astonishing specificity, but does so with poise and panache. While each chapter carefully constructs the totality of twelve individuals, Evaristo masterfully threads them together and in doing so, crafts a unified community of mothers and daughters grappling with life and love. Despite its massive concept, Evaristo breezily shows just how talented she is, free-flowing with ease and lyricism. She even manages to subtly shift her voice depending on which character's story she is telling, a nuance that truly lifts each character off the page.

Girl, Woman, Other üìö
 
I feel like I cannot give this book enough credit. It deserves so much. Each character is important, difficult, flawed, intriguing.
 
To quote myself: Evaristo employs her characters to think freely, and say things that perhaps are hard to hear, or disagree with your own philosophies, but that‚Äôs what makes it so interesting. 
We aren‚Äôt in an echo-chamber of likeminded individuals.
We are in a world, much like our own, where everyone is different, and everyone has their own opinions. A world where everyone is just trying to survive.
 
Find my full review on my blog now. The link is in my bio üîó

I may be behind the trends and a little late to the party but absolutely loving my #currentread Girl, Woman, Other. This book is definitely worth all the hype.
.
What I find most fascinating is how the definition of feminism is so different for each women cross generations and circumstance. The author has portrayed such a diverse range of voices and mores in such a compelling and empathetic way.
.
This is my first Bernadine Evaristo book. I‚Äôm curious to know - Have you read any of her other works?

An iron strong start to 2021 with this amazing novel, 'Girl, Woman, Other' by @bernardineevaristo bought as a Christmas present from my boyfriend.

I was absolutely captivated by each one of the 12 women's stories and I wished for each chapter to be longer. They were strong women who survived and thrived despite their unique circumstances. I loved the intimate and honest glimpse in the window of each of these complex women's lives. They felt real!

These are exactly the 3D women with dreams and flaws and secrets I have been dying to read! I loved how they all connected in some way. No woman is an island. 

This novel explores themes of grandmothers, mothers and daughters. Art. Aging. Abusive relationships. Friendship. Careers and fame. The importance of education. Cultural and historical ties to family. Racism, sexism, classism. Love. 

Stories and characters I've NEVER seen before in a novel. Even some Geordies üôå It really covers it all. 

Buyyyyy this book. It might take a few pages to really get into. You will NOT regret finishing.

'Girl, Woman, Other is about struggle, but it is also about love, joy and imagination' Guardian

'Evaristo's prose hums with life... At turns funny and sad, tender and true, this book deserves to win awards' Red

'Masterful... Achoral love song to black womanhood in modern Great Britain' Elle

Girl, Woman, Other follows the lives and struggles of twelve very different characters. Mostly women, black and British, they tell the stories of their families, friends and lovers, across the country and through the years.

Joyfully polyphonic and vibrantly contemporary, this is a gloriously new kind of history, a novel of our times: celebratory, ever-dynamic and utterly irresistible.

'If you don't yet know her work, you should - she says things about modern Britain that no one else does' Maggie Gee, Guardian

WINNER OF THE BOOKER PRIZE 2019

SHORTLISTED FOR THE GORDON BURN PRIZE 2019
.

üë©üèΩ‚Äçü¶±üë±üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Book experience üëµüèæüßïüèº

#qotd: How was your weekend ?

I finished Girl, Woman, Other and gearing up for a very busy week ahead . 

Now about the book ~~>
Let me begin by saying that this is the kind of fiction I have been craving for, since a long time. This booker prize winner ticks a lot of boxes in terms of what fiction of modern age should be like . Don‚Äôt we all really crave for books where LBBTQ is no more a genre and women are ambitious not just in non fictions, where caste and race is a topic but only in the background . I feel books like these is the need of the day. 

This book is a story of 12 characters , mostly women , black and British . I found it very modern because of the fact that it does not marginalise Gays and lesbians to only sexual desires and does not limit women to their issues of being a female. It goes beyond that , it highlights their life , as humans , with careers, struggles, achievements, aspirations and desires and so much more . 
All the characters are strong and flawed in their own unique ways .They are so brilliantly portrayed that I became a part part of each story and I loved that about the book . Every character was far from cliched portrayals and absolutely charming because of their originality.I felt I needed so much more of each character , I was kind of left craving for more every time a chapter ended.I adored how stories seeped into each other just enough to weave everything together. 

The writing style is being loved by so many and I absolutely get it . It made it so much easier to read as if it was flowing but I am a big sucker for beautifully written prose, well articulated sentences and carefully chosen words ,so I was not such a big fan . Although it dint bother me at all after first few pages. 

Overall , I feel this is a must read for everybody, it might change your perspective on a lot many aspects of society as it did for me .

What's your next read?

i actually read this a while ago, but never got round to writing about it.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I loved this, so much so, I miss the characters and would have happily continued to learn and listen about their lives as part of my daily to do.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
It‚Äôs a powerful, honest and witty ‚Äòdeep dive‚Äô into the successes, obstacles and prejudices that the 12 protagonists‚Äô face.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
It offers a multi perspective vision on race, sexuality and what it means to be a womxn today, as well as a pulled back view on ‚ÄòBritishness‚Äô. How interesting it was to read such differing opinions, reactions and thoughts, on some fundamentally similar experiences.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I highly recommend this.. I feel like I came out of it with 12 friends, of whom I would like an update on, in the near future.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Oh, there are no full stops. You forget about this about 15 pages in. Do we need full stops?
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

Girl, Woman, Other by Bernardine Evaristo ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è (5/5)
.
.
.
Just finished reading this yesterday and wow üòç I absolutely adored this book. It is about 12 different characters and how they lives subsequently intertwine. It focusses on the black community and rightly so, as it made me realise that I can‚Äôt remember a time I read a novel involving black characters, I tend to read novels that are predominantly centred around white individuals. Therefore, I aim to diversify my reading going forward ‚¨áÔ∏è
.
.
The story is beautiful written and I admit I had to google several words or phrases to understand their meaning, such as ‚ÄòMandem‚Äô meaning group of men. So I feel it has educated me in some way. It does cover some sensitive topics relating to sexual abuse, which I feel may be a trigger for some‚ùóÔ∏è‚ùóÔ∏è‚ùóÔ∏è
.
.
I admit at first I found the book hard to follow as it‚Äôs nearly void of punctuation with line breaks that seemed random at first, I found my self rereading sentences, but once you become familiar with the structure you don‚Äôt notice it. I also found the line breaks were not so much random but were to add emphasis to certain words. Anyone agree‚ùì
.
.
The (happyish) ending, depends how you look at it, made me feel emotional and I put the book down feeling in awe. So much so, I immediately searched for novels by the same author, they are now on my wish list ü•∞
.
.
#bookstagram #booklover #booklove #girlwomanother #girlwomanotherbernadineevaristo  #girlwomanotherbook #blacklivesmatter #bookishcommunity

I never knew that I didn‚Äôt know. I am humbled. I always thought I was pretty well educated about racism, but I‚Äôve learned I really have a lot to learn. So I will.

This past week I learned about ‚ÄúGirl, Woman, Other‚Äù by @bernardineevaristowriter from some of my UK book buddies. They recommended books by Black authors that discuss the challenges facing Black women from all walks of life. A winner of the 2019 Booker Prize (shared with Margaret Atwood) this novel follows the lives of 12 British Black women from age 19 to 93. Their stories intertwine and talk of their successes and failures, racism and assimilation.

I am looking forward to reading this novel, and more, and sharing my thoughts as well as, most important, continuing my growth.

#girlwomanother #girlwonanotherbook #bernadineevaristo #bernadineevaristowriter #girlwomanother #blackauthorsmatter #womenauthors #educateyourself #girlwomanotherbook bookstagram #reading #bookishladiesread #booksharks #dramafreenerdigans  #bookpalsüìö#ownvoice2020commitment

A rare beauty of a book that captures snapshots of predominantly Black, female-identifying characters, spanning across several decades and continents, creating an intricate web of interlinked lives.
The kind of novel that leaves you seeing the world and the people in it differently imo - couldn‚Äôt recommend more, ideally with an ice cold G&T in hand.

#bernardineevaristo #girlwomanother #girlwomanotherbook #whatireadnext #quarantinereads #bookclub #booksofinstagram #lockdownbooks #whatimreading #whattoread

I have never read a book without Punctuation (more like punctuated with space). I didn‚Äôt even know something like that existed. The spaces achieve the desired result of emphasising on certain words or sentences, quite effectively . 
Woman. Black. Sapphic - Sexism. Racism. Added dose of Heterosexism along with the other two.  It‚Äôs a collection of  interlinked short stories, of mostly black women and their ‚ÄòBritish experience‚Äô. It‚Äôs a feminist narrative of the challenges, the struggles, the stigma of surviving and living in a white patriarchal, hierarchical conservative society. Such stories need to be written and read many times over. It covers many social issues like feminism, racism, homophobia, sexual orientation, gender identity (including identifying with none), alternative life choices, gender roles, domestic violence, gaslighting, child abuse, rape, stereotypes, single motherhood, the belief that marriage and motherhood make a woman complete, babymothers, and the many forms that discrimination and exploitation take on. .. It gives a deeper understanding of the  people that make up the LGBT community, especially trans people and  non binary people, and successfully sensitises you. A much needed discourse in this day and age.

I really enjoyed this unconventional, poetic and colloquial style of writing. It‚Äôs humorous, sarcastic, sensitive, contemporary, progressive. A brilliant piece of work, a must read. #bernardineevaristo #girlwomanotherbook #fictionbooks #delhibookstafam #bookstagram #bookstagramfeature #africanliterature  #bookreviews #bookworm #booklover #winnerbookerprize2019 #mybookfeatures #quarantinereads #bookcommunity #lgbtfiction #feministfiction #bookaddict #ilovereading #africanauthors @womensprize #bookstagramindia #indianreaders #womenauthors @bernardineevaristo

ü¶ãGirl, Woman, Other by Bernardine Evaristoü¶ã

RATING: ü¶ãü¶ãü¶ãü¶ã ü¶ã/ 5

THOUGHTS: 
I often find myself unable to connect to UK black writers because of their inability to speak about intersectionality in a way that is parallel to my American experience. I gave it a chance last year when I read ‚ÄúQueenie‚Äù, but I was totally disappointed. Queenie is a book that although written by a black woman, it was intended for a different audience. I was skeptical of giving this book a chance due to the fear of it committing the same fallacy but I was wrong.
:

Girl, Woman, Other by Bernardine Evaristo follows 12(11+ 1 non-binary) British black women whose narratives are interwoven. This collection of stories is rich and represents the complexities of being a black woman. The best part of this book is how fully fledged each one of these characters is. Every one of their stories could stand alone and be it‚Äôs own book. I connected with each of these entities despite the flaws that many of them possessed. I rated this book a 5/5 because it was truly a masterpiece and totally deserving of the Booker Prize last year. :

If you enjoyed ‚ÄúHomegoing,‚Äù you‚Äôll truly love these intergenerational personal stories that tackle important issues such as racism, sexism, sexuality, classicism, gender identity, etc. Have you read this book? Who‚Äôs your favorite character!? I personally loved Dominique and Carole‚Äôs stories. Chapter 3 was just complete foolery ü•¥. :
